results.title: Kakadu: land of the crocodile (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Val Plumwood, environmental philosopher returns to Kakadu, where she was the victim of a crocodile attack. Against the backdrop of the steamy, intensely beautiful Kakadu National Park, viewers share her thoughts on wilderness and wildlife.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Greig, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions

results.title: Central Australia: tracks in the sand
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Cartoonist Michael Leunig records his impressions of Alice Springs, Ayers Rock and the vast emptiness of the Simpson Desert. Viewers are privy to a special meeting of minds and cultures, when he shares a canvas on the sand with Aboriginal artist, Michael Nelson. Accompanied by a Teacher’s guide.

results.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]
results.brief_description:
Western Stories: Expressions for the Future is an inspirational collection of works from young people who, through their association with the Western Chances program, have been given the opportunity to tell their stories and build their own bridge to the future.
Western Chances was established to ensure that financial hardship does not prevent a young person in Melbourne’s West from achieving their maximum potential in life.

results.title: The Australian story: overlanders of tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Doc K Sternberg and C G Scrimgeour
results.brief_description: The airlift of stud cattle to Brunette Downs Station in the Northern Territory for a stud stock sale is shown followed by the festivities held after the sale.

results.title: The Australian Opera favourites
results.brief_description: Presented by Peter Ross, this video brings together a popular selection of extracts from some of the world’s best operas. Highlights from the Australian Opera productions of ‘La Boheme’, ‘Il Trovatore’, ‘Tosca’, ‘A Masked ball’, ‘Lakme’, ‘La Traviata’, ‘The Merry widow’.

results.title: The Australian Royal Tours Collection 1901-1988
results.creator_credit: John Mandleberg, Film Australia and Aviva Ziegler
results.brief_description: A unique, visual cavalcade documenting the history of Australian tours by the British Royal Family since the turn of the century. It captures all the pomp and ceremony of the visits in the early 1900s by King George V, Edward the Prince of Wales and George VI, Queen Elizabeth’s first visit in 1954 and continues through to the younger generation of Royals with Diana and Fergie’s recent visits. Rated: G

results.title: The Australian National University
results.creator_credit: John Morris, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Surveys the teaching and research facilities of the Australian National University. Shows examples of investigations being pursued in microbiology, botany, geophysics, English, law, archaeology, Indonesian, literature, zoology, demography, astronomy, and political science. Photography: Tom Cowan; Music: Moneta Eagles.

results.title: Populate or perish
results.brief_description: Explores Australia’s population debate showing how after 50 years of continuous growth, new arguments about limiting Australia’s population are emerging. This program examines the post-war era when the cry to “Populate or perish” fostered Government sponsored immigration shemes, provided the applicants were white. It traces the gradual evolution of Australia as a multicultural society, primarily concentrated on the east coast.

results.title: Land of the long weekend
results.creator_credit: Sue Brooks, Susan Ardill and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Australia was the first country in the world to have a 40 hour working week, which accompanied by an array of public holidays, led to the identification of Australia as the working man’s paradise, a mythical land of the long weekend. This film examines how, in the face of deregulation and restructuring, long term unemployment and 24 hour trading, Australians have structured and restructured their time. Will Australians, drunk on sunshine, rally in time to save their precious weekend - or has it, in the drive to be flexible and efficient, already been lost?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sue Brooks, Susan Ardill and Film Australia
